docs.lead_paragraph: Gen. William J. Donovan, special assistant to the prosecution team at the Nuremberg war trials in 1945 and 1946, collected trial transcripts and documents that helped convict Nazi war criminals, as well as his own original photographs, letters, sketches and notes. In cooperation with Cornell University, which houses the collection, www.lawandreligion.com, the Web site of the Rutgers University Journal of Law and Religion, is now putting parts of it online, the first time such information has been made so easily available, said Julie Seltzer Mandel, a law student editing the material for posting. The first installment of the Nuremberg Project is ''The Nazi Master Plan: The Persecution of the Christian Churches' prepared by the German Office of Strategic Services. New information will be posted every six months. Karen DeMasters
docs.abstract: Rutgers University Journal of Law and Religion posts online part of collection of trial transcripts, documents and photos collected by Gen William J Donovan, special assistant to prosecution team at Nuremberg war crimes trials (By the Way column) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: While I sympathize with Iris Chang (''Betrayed by the White House,'' Op-Ed, Dec. 24), I fear that she overlooks a more insidious explanation for the White House's blocking of a Congressional bill that would have prevented federal agencies from opposing civil lawsuits by former prisoners of war against Japanese individuals or corporations. If the United States allows lawsuits by Americans used as slave labor in Japan to go forward, what will stop Japan from allowing lawsuits against the United States to be brought by survivors of the atomic explosions at Hiroshima and Nagasaki?

docs.lead_paragraph: Surrounded by weeping relatives and chanting monks, Ke Pauk, a Khmer Rouge leader blamed for 10,000 deaths, was buried this weekend by a small corps of former comrades who saluted him as a national hero. His death on Friday, at the age of 68, from natural causes, was also mourned around Cambodia by the many people who hated him. They had lost one of the last half dozen top Khmer Rouge leaders still alive and marked for possible indictment and trial.
docs.abstract: Cambodians are slowly realizing that no one may be brought to justice for deaths of more than million people under Khmer Rouge rule from 1975 to 1979, in wake of decision by UN to withdraw from negotiations on structure of international tribunal after five frustrating years of talks with Cambodian government; Sec Gen Kofi Annan says provisions of new Cambodian law to set up tribunal and government's refusal to modify them make it impossible to hold trial that would meet international standards of justice; impasse revives heated debate over whether flawed trial is better than no trial at all, and whether UN should bend to allow one to go forward before aging Khmer Rouge leaders die; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Rwandan courts had sentenced 660 people to death for crimes related to the 1994 genocide as of the end of last year, the Rwandan League for the Promotion and Defense of Human Rights said. Another 1,795 had been sentenced to life in prison, and 2,566 people were acquitted. The group said 115,000 people were in jail awaiting trial on charges of involvement in killing hundreds of thousands of members of the Tutsi ethnic group as well as some Hutus. Marc Lacey (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE chilling testimony of crimes against humanity by the Nazi regime in Hitler's Germany have been on the historical record since the Nuremberg war-crimes trials of 1945 and 1946. But any criminal prosecution, and especially one as mammoth as the case against Nazi Germany, consists of far more than public testimony in court. The Nuremberg trials were also built on many millions of pages of supporting evidence: documents, summaries, notes and memos collected by investigators. One of the leading United States investigators at Nuremberg, Gen. William J. Donovan -- Wild Bill Donovan of the O.S.S., the C.I.A.'s precursor -- collected and cataloged trial evidence in 148 bound volumes of personal papers that were stored after his death in 1959 at Cornell University. In 1999, Julie Seltzer Mandel, a law student from Rutgers University whose grandmother survived the Auschwitz death camp, read them. Under the Nuremberg Project, a collaboration between Rutgers and Cornell, she has edited the collection for publication on the Internet.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Russian Army officer who fled the battlefield as Moscow sent military forces into Chechnya in 1999 says that young fascist cadets in his elite airborne unit encouraged soldiers to execute civilians during the assault. The officer, Capt. Andrei Samorodov, a communications specialist in Russia's 21st Airborne Brigade, deserted his posting in November 1999 and moved his wife and two children into a village in the Russian countryside. Later he made his way to Mexico, took a bus to the United States border, forded the Rio Grande near Laredo, Tex., and turned himself in to surprised Border Patrol officers.
